title: Metformin in the Prevention of Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: Hyperinsulinemia and type 2 diabetes (T2D) are important potential risk factors for cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease (AD). Two thirds of the US adult population are at risk for hyperinsulinemia and T2D, and half of the population 85 years and older have AD. Peripheral hyperinsulinemia can impair the clearance of amyloid beta in the brain, the main culprit in AD. Thus, the investigators hypothesize that lowering peripheral insulin in overweight persons with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (AMCI), a transition state between normal cognition and AD, can decrease the risk of cognitive decline and progression to AD. The investigators propose to conduct a phase II double blinded placebo controlled randomized clinical trial of metformin, a safe and effective medication that prevents hyperinsulinemia and diabetes, to test this hypothesis among 80 overweight persons aged 55 to 90 years with AMCI. The main outcome of the study will be changes in performance in a memory test (total recall of the Selective Reminding Test) and the Score a test of general cognitive function used in clinical trials (the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-Cog)). Another aim is to compare brain function in an area affected by Alzheimer's disease between the metformin and placebo group mean changes from beginning to end among 40 participants using a PET scan.
description_detailed:
The prevalence of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is expected to quadruple by the year 2047. There are no known curative or preventive measures for AD. Current treatment options for AD only address symptoms, and no treatments are available that focus on delaying the actual disease process. One of the currently accepted hypothesis of the pathogenesis of AD is that the main culprit is the accumulation of Aβ in the brain, and this process has become a target for treatments and preventive measures. Amnestic mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has been used to describe a transitional state between normal cognitive function and AD, and has thus been targeted for interventions. Persons with MCI progress to AD at the rate of nearly 10% to 15% per year. The criteria most commonly used for the definition of AD dementia from MCI. The investigators propose to use these criteria with slight modification to recruit persons for a pilot trail of AD prevention in persons with amnestic MCI.

Peripheral hyperinsulinemia (high insulin levels) potentially impair Aβ clearance, and in this study we are proposing to use metformin, an insulin lowering agent, to prevent AD by improving Aβ clearance in the brain. The insulin resistance syndrome and hyperinsulinemia are common in individuals with and without diabetes, and are related to increased risk of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes. Hyperinsulinemia predicts the development of diabetes; therefore, diabetes can be considered a consequence and a marker of past hyperinsulinemia. According to NHANES III data, more than 40% of the population over the age of 60 years has problems of glucose intolerance or diabetes, all related to insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. The investigators have found that the risk of AD in individuals without diabetes increases with increasing levels of fasting insulin, and that high insulin levels are related to a faster decline in memory scores. The high prevalence of hyperinsulinemia and diabetes (49% of the elderly in Northern Manhattan) and its biological plausibility as a risk factor for cognitive decline and AD has attracted increasing attention. In this application we are targeting hyperinsulinemia, the most important risk factor for AD identified in the elderly population of Northern Manhattan. The risk of AD attributable to hyperinsulinemia or diabetes in Northern Manhattan was 39%, and is higher in Hispanics and African-Americans, who have a higher prevalence of diabetes and insulin resistance, and will comprise the majority of our sample.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 1426 screened by telephone and 1095 excluded; 331 deemed eligible for in-person screen; 224 of those were excluded; 87 met eligibility criteria, 7 declined randomization, 80 were randomized
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Recruitment was completed in 32 months (2.5 subjects a month) \[38\]; 1426 subjects were screened by telephone and 331 were screened in person.

measures.title: APOE Epsilon 4

measures.title: Score of the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-cog)
measures.description: The ADAS-cog is an aggregate for several cognitive tests intended to provide a global cognitive score and consists of 11 tasks. The tasks (and corresponding score range)) are Word Recall (0-10), Naming (0-4), Commands (0-5), Constructional Praxis (0-5) Ideational Praxis (0-5), Orientation (0-8), Word Recognition (0-12), Language (0-5), Word Finding Difficulty (0-5), and Remembering Test Instructions (1-5). The range of aggregate scores (sum of scores) is 1 to 69, with higher scores meaning worse cognitive performance.

measures.title: Selective Reminding Test Total Recall score
measures.description: The Selective Reminding Test measures verbal learning and delayed recall through a multiple-trial list-learning paradigm. Patients are presented aurally with a list of 12 words for trial 1 and are asked to recall as many as possible. For trials 2-6, there is a selective presentation of only those words not recalled on the previous trial. Trial 7 is similar to the other trials but is assessed after an 11-minute delay. The score for the selective reminding test is the unweighted average of seven individual study results (min=0 and max=84) Higher scores indicate a better cognitive performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Total Recall Score in the Selective Reminding Test
outcomeMeasures.description: The Selective Reminding Test measures verbal learning and delayed recall through a multiple-trial list-learning paradigm. Patients are presented aurally with a list of 12 words for trial 1 and are asked to recall as many as possible. For trials 2-6, there is a selective presentation of only those words not recalled on the previous trial. Trial 7 is similar to the other trials but is assessed after an 11-minute delay. The score for the selective reminding test is the unweighted average of seven individual study results (min=0 and max=84) Higher scores indicate a better cognitive performance. The total recall score from the first visit was subtracted from that of the last visit to calculate the change in score (total words recalled).

analyses.estimateComment: The difference is the value for the metformin arm minus the value for the placebo arm.
The difference is the value for the metformin arm minus the value for the placebo arm.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Score of the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive Subscale (ADAS-cog)
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADAS-cog is an aggregate for several cognitive tests intended to provide a global cognitive score and consists of 11 tasks. The tasks (and corresponding score range)) are Word Recall (0-10), Naming (0-4), Commands (0-5), Constructional Praxis (0-5) Ideational Praxis (0-5), Orientation (0-8), Word Recognition (0-12), Language (0-5), Word Finding Difficulty (0-5), and Remembering Test Instructions (1-5). The range of aggregate scores (sum of scores) is 1 to 69, with higher scores meaning worse cognitive performance. The change was calculated subtracting the baseline score from the final visit score.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analyses used an intent to treat approach with last observation carried forward

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Relative Glucose Uptake (rCMRg) in the Posterior Cingulate-precuneus.
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in relative glucose uptake (rCMRgl) in the posterior cingulate-precuneus measured with subscale (ADAS-Cog) from brain \[18\]F-labeled 2-deoxy-2-fluoro-D-glucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET). The unit for rCMRgl is %. The results presented are absolute differences in rCMRgl, presented in % units; the change was calculated subtracting the baseline rCMRgl from the follow-up rCMRgl
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Out of 40 persons recruited in the imaging sub study, 33 underwent a 12 month scan (18 in the placebo group, 15 in the metformin group).

limitationsAndCaveats.description: The pilot study had a small sample size and relatively short duration, both for the whole sample, and the imaging sub-sample

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is metformin, a small‑molecule biguanide antihyperglycemic that lowers peripheral insulin and hepatic glucose production; the trial tests whether lowering peripheral insulin will reduce risk of cognitive decline/progression to AD (a disease‑modification hypothesis rather than symptomatic cognitive boosting). citeturn0search5turn0search0

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase II of metformin in overweight persons with amnestic MCI measuring cognitive outcomes (SRT total recall, ADAS‑Cog) and brain PET changes. This matches a prior pilot RCT description of metformin in aMCI. citeturn0search2turn0search4

Supportive evidence / web search results: (a) metformin pilot RCT in amnestic MCI with same design and outcomes. citeturn0search2 (b) Mechanistic literature showing metformin reduces fasting insulin and hepatic glucose production (mechanism relevant to lowering peripheral hyperinsulinemia). citeturn0search0turn0search5 (c) Reviews/observational analyses and trials exploring metformin’s association with lower dementia risk and its repurposing for cognitive prevention. citeturn0search6turn0search1

Reflect: Although metformin does not directly bind amyloid or tau (i.e., it is not an anti‑amyloid biologic), the trial’s stated goal is to alter an upstream metabolic risk factor to prevent progression to AD — this is an intended disease‑modifying strategy implemented with a small‑molecule drug, so the best fit among the provided categories is 'disease-targeted small molecule'. Ambiguity: one could argue it is a metabolic risk–factor intervention rather than a classical AD‑pathology‑targeting drug, but by category definitions (small molecule intended to modify disease course) it fits. citeturn0search2turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is metformin, a biguanide antihyperglycemic that lowers hepatic glucose production and peripheral insulin and activates cellular energy‑sensing pathways (AMPK / effects on mitochondrial complex I), so the trial is altering metabolic/bioenergetic risk factors for AD rather than directly targeting amyloid or tau. citeturn0search6turn0search4

Act: Extracted details — drug: metformin (small‑molecule, repurposed antihyperglycemic); trial population and design match prior pilot randomized, placebo‑controlled studies in amnestic MCI measuring SRT total recall, ADAS‑Cog and brain PET. This intervention’s mechanism and trial goal (lower peripheral insulin / modify metabolic risk) map to CADRO category J (Metabolism and Bioenergetics). citeturn1search1turn1search2

Reflect: Metformin does not directly bind or clear classical AD proteinopathies (amyloid or tau), so categories A or B are not appropriate. The study targets systemic and brain energy/metabolic pathways (insulin signaling, hepatic gluconeogenesis, AMPK/mitochondrial effects), which fits CADRO J better than a multi‑target or "Other" label. Evidence on cognition/dementia risk is mixed and observational/meta‑analytic—supportive but not definitive—so J is the most specific, accurate CADRO assignment given the description. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Web search results used (key sources): (1) Pilot RCT: "Metformin in Amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment: Results of a Pilot Randomized Placebo Controlled Clinical Trial" (Luchsinger et al., full text). citeturn1search1turn1search2 (2) Mechanistic reviews on metformin’s actions (AMPK activation, complex I / inhibition of hepatic gluconeogenesis). citeturn0search6turn0search4 (3) Systematic reviews / meta‑analyses of metformin and dementia/cognitive outcomes (mixed findings, time‑bias concerns). citeturn0search3turn0search1 (4) Additional meta‑analytic evidence on dementia risk and metformin. citeturn0search0
